posts.name: Micah Doberne-Schor
posts.cooked:
Hi Chief Delphi,
Our team is looking to improve our can wiring this offseason. We plan to switch from daisy chaining to a star can wiring system, where each device has its own can wire route, and a break in the loop doesn’t cause complete failure of the entire robot at the match.

Are there any good terminals that we should use to split the wire into a terminal for multiple connections (if this makes any sense; like where the central can wire splits off to connect to each device in the can network)?

Thank you.

posts.name: Noah
posts.cooked:

### Step 1: Analyze the Original Text

### Cleaned-Up Text

posts.name: Saber_8871
posts.cooked: We have used WAGO connectors for the past two seasons and they were a godsend when we had a CAN fault mid-competition. We put ferrule crimps on the ends of our wires to ensure solid connections rather than replacing the faulty component at the last minute.

posts.name: Justin
posts.cooked: The assistant effectively cleaned up the provided text by removing HTML tags and unnecessary elements, ensuring the content remains coherent and preserves its original meaning. The final result is a well-formatted, single paragraph that maintains the intended message without introducing any additional content or alterations.

posts.name: Graham Howard
posts.cooked: When using a star CAN abbreviation, you must be highly disciplined regarding stub length. For CAN 2.0B, such as the Rio employs, only 0.3m (approximately 12in) is specified. Issues may not occur beyond this length, yet be aware that exceeding this isn't officially supported. For CAN FD, since the CTRE Canivore uses it, there's no safe stub length; thus, avoiding star topology is advised. Instead of pursuing star, investigate why your CAN bus is failing—whether due to connector problems or other factors—and address those root causes.

posts.name: Robin
posts.cooked:
I don’t have much experience, so I don’t think this approach will work. CAN requires 120Ω terminations on both ends, and having multiple ends could lead to unwanted issues. For more details, visit [this link](https://www.ti.com/lit/an/slla270/slla270.pdf), which I'm referencing mainly from page 7.

In terms of network topologies, a star setup has a single point of failure—losing connection means losing all links. A bus topology introduces additional potential points of failure, though at least one remains. What do people think about this configuration? It uses two terminations but depends on the CAN standard's unspecified behavior, which isn't exactly straightforward.

posts.name: Pedro Braga
posts.cooked: Here we go again... Additionally, if you're looking for connectors, I think going for the style AzMaverick suggested is a good idea. Moreover, if your budget permits, seeking genuine Wagos might be worth considering. Furthermore, if you're interested in more star can information, there are several threads available, some of which contain lively discussions on the subject.

posts.name: Pedro Braga
posts.cooked: Creating loops with different lengths will create interference in communication, so this will probably not work. I’d be glad to be proven wrong, if you have the time to test it.

posts.name: Nick Foote
posts.cooked:
I wouldn’t go for a star configuration, but I’d suggest using a trunk and branch topology. There’s an entire OA post on our wiring that might address your needs; the link takes you to [the post](https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/2102-build-thread-2024-25-open-alliance/476375/3). Here are my key tips:

- **Ensure your main trunk is protected.** It won’t improve reliability if it’s compromised by another robot or mechanisms snaking into it.

- **Keep your stubs off the main branch from being too lengthy.** This applies to the extra length on both sides of the device. One end of your motor’s CAN communication must be cut very short.

- **Invest in high-quality connectors.**

- Avoid using wagos as splitters. Opt for an open barrel crimp and connect multiple wires together for splits.

This structured approach should guide you toward effective wiring solutions.

posts.name: Travis Hoffman
posts.cooked:
The SWYFT CANnect Wiring System simplifies robot wiring by enabling CAN bus and 12V power over standard Ethernet cables, reducing the complexity of wiring setups. This innovative approach drastically streamlines the process compared to traditional methods.  

The system retails for $39.99 and offers a reliable solution with no CAN-related issues reported during its use across multiple seasons. Its design uses Ethernet cables as the trunk, connecting short branches (Wago connections) directly to devices such as the Canivore. While effective for applications like swerve drives and other base connections, alternative methods like daisy chaining may be suitable depending on specific needs.

posts.name: billjester3
posts.cooked: Is it feasible to use a CAN bus for a swerve drive train but then continue the same bus as a daisy-chain connection to other components? Would this require setting up a separate CAN bus (e.g., Canivore) or can it work with just one CAN bus? Our plan is to implement CAN bus functionality for the drivetrain during the offseason, but we’d prefer to keep the rest of the system integrated if possible.

posts.name: Tauseef Afraz
posts.cooked: Yes. Everything comes back to the Inject. If you turn off the resistor, you will have a CAN Controller Area Network out port.

posts.name: billjester3
posts.cooked:
So like:  
Rio -> Inject (term switch off) -> other stuff -> Resistor  
         | (cat5)  
-> Direct -> Direct -> Direct -> Direct (loop switch on)

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked:
Daisy chains, trunks, and branches are essentially the same in electrical terms but differ in cable length. Daisy chains feature very short branches, typically just traces on PCBs within each device. In contrast, star configurations have much longer branches, which pose significant challenges for wiring robots under the Rio's ~12-inch CAN specifications. My team doesn't use CANivores; however, we've decided against adopting that standard.

Establishing a reliable CAN network prioritizes the reliability of individual connections over the number of potential failure points. Daisy chaining leads to unreliable JST PH connectors, which can disrupt the entire network when replaced. Additionally, every installation requires accessing and replacing devices along the trunk, complicating maintenance. While some suppliers offer can wires with an extra loop to prevent breaking the network upon disconnection, using REV's crimped wires exceeds their rating, weakening the grip and damaging housings. Threading's solution involves soldering loops outside the JST connector to avoid such issues.

We recommend trunk and branch configuration due to its flexibility. This setup allows selecting appropriate connectors for the trunk and ensures careful strain relief, preventing future trunk adjustments. Our team uses Wago 222-413 and 222-415 VHBed-down connectors for trunks, which are highly reliable. For branches, we create custom 4-inch-long JST PH pig tails using 24-gauge mil-spec wire, resulting in consistent performance and reliability.

posts.name: Tauseef Afraz
posts.cooked: Inject CAN Out → other CAN devices connected via a 120 ohm termination resistor. Upstream signals are routed to RIO CAN, which injects these signals onto Ethernet media directly. A loopback mechanism is implemented where the direct connection between the RIO CAN and the downstream Ethernet device is replaced with a loop switch configuration, ensuring stable signal integrity within the internal network loop.

posts.cooked:

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: I'm not an expert in electrical engineering, but I believe the "loopback" you're referring to is simply a twisted pair of cables within the Ethernet cable that connects back to the terminator resistor for testing or signal feedback. I'm unsure why the diagram shows it connecting to the RIO (Receive Input Output) instead of the terminator.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Pretty sure Wago lever connectors rely on high surface area and compressing the strands, making Furrlies a poor choice. This is a debated topic on this forum…

Not that Furrlies won’t work (they do) but the wires may pull out more easily. The resistance in the connection isn’t an issue with CAN (or any signal wire in FRC), but may be with power.

By a similar token, twisting the wires after stripping them is poor practice. The connection will still work, but it reduces the mechanical holding power of the connector and the contact area.

IMO proper soldering is the most secure option, failing that, minimize the footguns used with your chosen connector (e.g., use zip ties, proper strain relief, hot glue).
